comments.body: Thanks for noticing this and creating the issue.
Is this to get around the const?
Please add a comment to the ignore explaining why it is there per our style guide.
Yes, `.isNotEmpty` isn't const.  I'll add a comment about it.
I wonder if we need to worry about if the animation is on going
That's a great catch, it would be potentially possible for the animation to navigate to a non-existent page.  I'll fix this by resetting the animation here.
for my own understanding: When does the toolbar show a disabled button? I thought if there is no page to go to it just doesn't show a button?

From my experimentation, the only time it won't show a next button is if there is only one page.  Otherwise there is always a next button, and on the last page it's disabled.

![Screen Shot 2020-04-10 at 11 06 03 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/389558/79012504-4d557100-7b1b-11ea-86f2-e1eec148b7d3.png)
Interesting. I never noticed that. Thanks for the explanation.

comments.body: nit: throughout the PR you sometimes do `.keys.contains`, sometimes `.containsKey`. Maybe unify? (I would pick `.containsKey`)
Are there reasons why this couldn't be an MultiChildRenderObjectElement. In method overrides it would handle the cupertinoSlots and otherwise call super to handle the regular children?
(or should we create a ContainerElementMixin similar to the ContainerRenderObjectMixin to make this easier)?

I tried extending MultiChildRenderObjectElement when I wrote this and the reason I decided to do it this way instead was that I sometimes needed to call the super method on RenderObjectElement without going through MultiChildRenderObjectElement.

An example is `forgetChild`.  For a child that exists in `slotToChild`, I need to remove the child, then I need to call RenderObjectElement's forgetChild without calling MultiChildRenderObjectElement's forgetChild.  Let me know if I'm wrong, but I thought that was a showstopper since I can't do `super.super.forgetChild`.

Maybe a mixin will work though!  I'll try that right now.
What is wrong if  we call MultiChildRenderObjectElement's forgetchild?

@chunhtai Sorry, I missed your question because I didn't refresh.  Calling MultiChildRenderObjectElement's forgetChild with a slotted child will add it to _forgottenChildren, which is only used for list children.

I did work around this in the mixin I pasted above, though.
uber-nit: move this section above the _backButton section to have all RenderBox properties in one block?
This is surprising. Where is this requirement coming from? Naively, I would have expected that each page can be as wide as it wants?

My conclusion after playing around with native iOS is that it tries to keep the width of the menu constant:

![width](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/389558/79021707-1b4f0980-7b31-11ea-9222-3abed14e499e.gif)
Interesting observation. Thanks for the gif.
We have to do this for all children? Even the ones that are after the page currently visible?
No, you're right.  I tried making this optimization earlier but got console errors about children that weren't laid out.  I just had to implement visitChildrenForSemantics and it fixed it though.
Is this necessary when it gets overwritten by line 931?
Now it is!  Since I made the optimization above where I don't layout all children, line 931 doesn't get run on all children.
Maybe also reset _nextPage to null? (I don't think this is a visual bug, but it may be strange during debugging if this is set to something that's no longer valid.)
Just a FYI, this currently only work with word boundary. If for some reason the space is not enough, copy -> ... Paste -> ...    select all -> select ...
I think somehow it's working ok, see this screenshot if I add a bunch of A's to Paste. Is that what you mean?
oh nvm it seems you are right.
